monogr.title: The martyr'd souldier : as it was sundry times acted with a generall applause at the Private House in Drury lane, and at other publicke theaters. By the Queenes Majesties servants. The author H. Shirley Gent
monogr.author: Shirley, Henry

div.head: To the Courteous Reader.
div.p:
TO make too large an explanation of this following Poem, were but to beguile thy appetite, and somewhat dull thy expectation; but the worke it selfe being now an Orphant, and wanting him to protect that first begot it, it were an iniury to his memory to passe him unspoken of: For the man, his Muse was much Courted, but no common mistresse; and though but seldome seene abroad, yet ever much admired at: This worke not the meanest of his labours has much adorned not only one, but many Stages, with such a generall applause;
as it hath drawne even the Rigid Stoickes of the Time, who though not for pleasure, yet for profit, have gathered something out of his plentifull Vineyard. My hopes are, it wil prove no lesse pleasing to the Reader, then it has formerly beene to the Spectators; and so prooving, I have my aime and full desire, fare-well.
